Hypenotic The Jekyll Butler

Who Knew The Pre-Show Would be so Interesting?

18 Oct 2010

My buddy Joshna and I decided to watch a movie. Well, to be more specific, we decided to watch Fiddler on the Roof–a movie that strangely (being a Jewish girl) I had never seen before and Joshna had strangely (being an Indian/South African girl) had watched endlessly as a child.

We set the date and the build-up began. It started with Twitter references, but by the time the event rolled around it had become epic including a trip to Queen Video for the movie rental,  Caplanskys‘ smoked meat sandwiches and fabulous Manischewitz cocktails. Maybe that doesn’t sound epic to you, but you might feel differently after you’ve seen the (slap-dash) video about what happened before the Fiddler fiddled his first note.

This video shows how much “content” exists before the main event even takes place. By having a camera in hand and doing a couple of context shots, I can give folks a pretty good sense of where the evening is headed. You can do the same for your videos–which will inevitably be less exciting than the night Jodi + Joshna watched Fiddler on the Roof, but nothing can be done about that, can it?

Here are some ideas for shooting a pre-event video:

  • *Give context: *Joshna walking through the doorway, the Caplanskys sign–these all tell you where you are in the video. If you don’t have that footage you can always use transition slides (Slides that say “Then we went to get some deli” but it’s not quite as fun.
  • *Decide what is worthy of ‘build up’ and what will be of interest to your audience. *Is it the dress rehearsal? The pre-game talk? The dressing of the room?
  • *Plan but don’t over-plan. *I couldn’t have known that the girl at the video store would be so cute and forthcoming had I not been intrepid enough to ask her a few key questions. Turns out she was awesome.
  • *Keep it short. *People have short attention spans. Stuff can be interesting, but only for so long
  • Jazz it up. Music is key to keeping people’s attention. It can add romance to a non-event like buying some deli
  • *Interview everyone. *Some of the answers you get will be worth keeping, others won’t. But, keep asking and talking
